projects.title: Doakes Helper
paragraphs: So far, this is my proudest after-hours project. It has accumulated more than 25,000 unique users over the lifespan of 4+ years. This desktop application still serves many GTA SA-MP players as a companion app.
Users have donated over $300 to support the project, submitted bug reports and even uploaded YouTube videos that showcase or explain it.

projects.title: Context Switch
paragraphs: This fun project helped me utilize my PC and my laptop at the same time without moving my hands off my PC's keyboard and mouse.
Context Switch is a desktop application that lets you seamlessly switch the targets of your keyboard, mouse and headphones between two devices. All you have to do is click the hotkey and - voila!

projects.title: Blog for my Argentina trip
paragraphs: I only had 3 weeks to spend in Argentina, and I had absolutely no intention to make dozens of phone calls to friends and family; repeating the same story over and over, sending photos on WhatsApp.

I wrote a dynamic blog from scratch (the majority of the code was written during the long flight), then refined it slightly throughout the trip. I consider it a success, because even my 58 years old mom managed to browse the blog!

projects.title: Election system for my high-school
paragraphs: The 2015 Israeli elections were just 3 weeks away when my teacher approached me and asked if I would be willing to create an election system for our high school.
I assembled a team with two more classmates. Together we created a responsive web application, where students used their ID to sign in, cast their votes and even view a graph of the results.
Even though we barely had time to test this system, the election day went by smoothly and we appeared on 3 different local newspapers.

projects.title: Simple analytics tool for websites & apps
paragraphs: I swear - I tried to use google analytics, but the overwhelming interface that I encountered in 2014 pushed me away. Well, I enjoy reinventing the wheel anyway, so I created my own little analytics system, with a goal of keeping it simple.
In fact, this utility collects just enough data about the users of my apps, that I never even needed to use another one.
It answers essential questions, such as "How many unique users do I have? How much time do they spend using my app? Which web pages do they use?"

projects.title: Keyboard Hook NuGET package
paragraphs: One of my WPF projects required global hotkeys, so that users could interact with it while playing games. I knew registering a keyboard hook could seem like a malicious operation, but I had to use it -- yet I still wanted to be transparent with my users.
And so, I coded an open-source NuGET package that allows registering specific hotkeys, but not the recording of all keystrokes.

projects.title: Custom HUD for GTA:SA
paragraphs: An open source desktop application that enhances the experience of GTA:SA players by adding a custom HUD that tells them where they are.

The creation of this project involved reverse engineering, memory injection and other low-level skills that are normally "out of my scope". However, I really wanted to make it work, so I just kept on going until I made it work.

projects.title: GTA V Animation Wheel
paragraphs: After demonstrating my skills to GTA:SA communities over the past 4 years, a GTA V community manager reached out to me to ask if I'd be willing to lend a hand.
The customizable animation wheel is rendered by a fragile in-game browser. So fragile, that developers often use vanilla javascript.
The community (gta.world) integrated this open source project into their game-mode and the community was super grateful for it.
